title: App Annie Settles SEC Fraud Probe Over Mobile-Data Product
summary: Enforcement case is first against a provider of alternative data used by traders. WASHINGTON-A company that collects and sells mobile-app usage statistics agreed to pay $10 million to settle a fraud investigation over how it disclosed its data practices to trading clients.

title: New iPhone 13 Pro and Watch Series 7 Unveiled at Apple Event
summary: Latest iPhone lineup includes models offering longer battery life, new camera features, optional memory upgrades. After weeks of turbulent headlines, Tim Cook took the virtual stage in an attempt to return attention to the key driver of Apple Inc.'s success: the iPhone.

title: Amazon Adding 125,000 Workers, Opening Dozens of Facilities
summary: Company has hired hundreds of thousands of employees throughout the Covid-19 pandemic. Amazon.com Inc. said it plans to add 125,000 employees in the U.S. and has lifted its average starting wage as it continues to rapidly expand its vast warehouse operations in a tight labor market.

title: Hartford Increases Boy Scouts Insurance Settlement to $787 Million
summary: The deal between Hartford and the Boy Scouts would resolve abuse claims arising under policies issued to the youth group, mostly from the 1970s. Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. has struck a revised deal with the Boy Scouts of America that increases compensation the insurer would provide victims of childhood sexual abuse, an agreement that could help the youth group ultimately emerge from bankruptcy.

title: New iPhone 13, Pro, Pro Max and Mini vs. Earlier Models: Apple's Full Lineup Compared
summary: Need help deciding among the eight (yes, eight!) existing models? Here's how the latest options stack up against the reduced-price leftovers. Once upon a time, in the year 2007, there was one iPhone introduced by one man.

title: Russia's Putin Self-Isolating After Covid-19 Exposure in Inner Circle
summary: President is healthy and was tested for the virus, press secretary says. Russian President Vladimir Putin is self-isolating after being exposed to several people with Covid-19 but was tested for the virus and "is absolutely healthy," his press secretary said Tuesday.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Mandates Put Hospitals, Nurses at Odds
summary: A judge in New York halts part of the state's inoculation mandate for medical workers. A federal judge weakened New York state's mandate for medical workers to be vaccinated against Covid-19, a win for nurses and other staff who have lost their jobs elsewhere in the country over their refusal to get the shots.

title: Tropical Storm Nicholas Hits Texas, Prompts Flash-Flood Warnings
summary: Parts of Louisiana might see as much as 20 inches of rain; more than 240,000 in Texas without power. Tropical Storm Nicholas flooded roadways and caused widespread power outages along parts of the Texas coast Tuesday, as officials in Louisiana prepared for heavy rain and dangerous flash flooding.

title: Prosecution Witnesses in Theranos Trial to Support Claim Elizabeth Holmes Lied
summary: The blood-testing startup's former controller testifies that she had no idea where the company came up with some financial projections. SAN JOSE, Calif.-Theranos Inc. gave investors far rosier revenue projections than what the company's finance staff expected, jurors heard Tuesday during the second day of witness testimony in Elizabeth Holmes's criminal fraud trial.

title: Blitzing the Senate Parliamentarian
summary: Democrats are trying to sneak huge policy shifts through budget reconciliation.. Spending $3.5 trillion on a budget bill apparently doesn't satisfy the progressive imperative. Democrats control the 50-50 Senate thanks only to the Vice President as tiebreaker, and they lack the votes to nuke the filibuster. Nevertheless, they insist that their mammoth budget bill must also include big policy changes, even if it takes bending Senate rules beyond recognition.

title: Defining Inflation Down
summary: Voters know how much prices are rising even if politicians don't.. We're old enough to remember a time-earlier this year-when 5.3% consumer-price inflation was considered high. No longer. Nowadays when price rises hit that pace, as they did in August, everyone's supposed to relax because that means inflation is moderating.

title: Europe's Climate Lesson for America
summary: As wind power flags, energy prices are soaring amid fuel shortages.. Energy prices are soaring in Europe, and the effects are rippling across the Atlantic. Blame anti-carbon policies of the kind that the Biden Administration wants to impose in the U.S.

title: Another Carried-Interest Carveout
summary: Democrats spare real-estate partnerships from a longer holding period.. Whenever a tax increase is announced, reach for your stopwatch: It usually doesn't take long for politicians to make exceptions for friends and donors. So it is with the so-called crackdown on carried interest.

title: Did China Get It Right on Videogames?
summary: Students debate Beijing's new gaming ban.. Editor's note: This Future View discusses China's ban on youth videogaming during the week and three-hour time limit on weekends. Next we'll ask about the growing gender gap at U.S. colleges: "Where did all the men go, and what does their absence signify?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Sept. 21. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Let the Courts Speak on Covid
summary: The Biden vaccine mandates will bring out basic truths about the pandemic.. The good news about the Joe Biden vaccine mandates is that lawyers and judges will now have both incentive and duty to supply clear thinking about Covid, which has been lacking. The subjects they will necessarily have to tackle include:

title: A Final Farewell to the Class of 1951
summary: There was faith in the future at my last high school reunion.. Bellingham, Wash.

title: Big Truckers Say Vaccine Mandate Could Push Drivers Away
summary: Companies worry that testing requirement also poses logistics hurdle for workers on the road. Big trucking companies say a federal vaccination and testing mandate aimed at curbing the spread of the Covid-19 virus could push more workers away from their operations and deepen upheaval in U.S. supply chains.

title: 'Uncontrolled Spread' Review: Tested and Found Wanting
summary: A former Food and Drug Administration commissioner surveys what went wrong with America's response to the Covid pandemic.. Scott Gottlieb is uniquely qualified to write a book on America's response to the Covid-19 pandemic. Physician, former Food and Drug Administration commissioner, board member for both pharmaceutical giant Pfizer and genetic sequencing firm Illumina and presidential adviser: Dr. Gottlieb saw the crisis from multiple angles. His book "Uncontrolled Spread" is everything you'd hope: a smart and insightful account of what happened and, currently, the best guide to what needs to be done to avoid a future pandemic.

title: The Case for Covid Booster Shots Is Strong
summary: Severe Covid infections that aren't defeated quickly can lead to long-lasting complications.. The Biden administration's plan to start rolling out Covid-19 booster shots next week has drawn criticism from some who claim there's not enough evidence to show they're needed. While breakthrough infections among the fully vaccinated have increased, most of those cases aren't severe. The purpose of vaccines, say booster critics, is to prevent hospitalizations and deaths, not cold-like symptoms.

title: Is Racial Gerrymandering Going Out of Style?
summary: Some liberals are coming around to the view that white voters will elect black candidates.. With apologies to Stephen Sondheim, a funny thing has happened in the redistricting battles leading up to next year's midterm elections. Democrats have discovered that divvying up voters by race might not be such a good idea.

title: Notable & Quotable: Norm Macdonald
summary: 'The model used to be: admit wrongdoing, show complete contrition and then we give you a second chance. Now it's admit wrongdoing and you're finished. And so the only way to survive is to deny, deny, deny.'. From a 2018 Hollywood Reporter interview with comedian Norm Macdonald, who died Tuesday at 61:

title: Alleged New York Mobsters Arrested on Extortion, Racketeering Charges
summary: They include members of Colombo and Bonanno crime families, which once helped rule New York's underworld but have seen their power wane in recent years. The reputed boss of the Colombo crime family and nine other alleged members and associates of the Mafia were arrested Tuesday morning on fraud and racketeering charges involving loan-sharking, money-laundering and the shakedown of a construction-industry union, according to an indictment unsealed in federal court in Brooklyn.

title: Biden Vaccine Mandate Faces Arizona Legal Challenge
summary: Legal scholars question Arizona attorney general's ability to sue before the mandate policy is in place. The Republican attorney general of Arizona filed a lawsuit Tuesday to stop the Biden administration from imposing Covid-19 vaccine requirements for tens of millions of workers, marking the first legal salvo against the president's mandate policy.

title: Comcast Stock Falls After Warning on Slowing Subscriber Growth
summary: After strong recent growth, CFO Mike Cavanagh says he saw 'a little bit of a slowdown' in August. Cable giant Comcast Corp. said it was experiencing a slowdown in its cable business after surging growth in the early stages of the coronavirus pandemic, a warning that triggered a slide in the company's stock price.

title: Democrats Put Off Decisions on $3.5 Trillion Spending Plan for Now
summary: Lawmakers seek intraparty consensus on healthcare, education and climate-change programs amid united Republican opposition. WASHINGTON-Democrats on Capitol Hill have hard choices to make if they want to pass a sprawling package of healthcare, education and climate-change programs without any GOP support. So far, they have avoided making them.

title: New iPad Mini and Apple Watch Series 7: See All of Apple's Changes
summary: All-new Mini tablet costs $499 and up, while the Apple Watch with larger display, coming later this fall, starts at $399. In a world where screens seem to only get bigger with each passing year, I have to give credit to Apple for innovating on its little devices. I'm someone with small hands who directly benefits from the company's mini strategy.

title: Comedian Norm Macdonald Dies of Cancer at 61
summary: The former 'Saturday Night Live' performer anchored show's Weekend Update segment. Norm Macdonald, the sardonic comedian who anchored the "Weekend Update" for NBC's "Saturday Night Live" in the mid-1990s, has died from cancer. He was 61 years old.

title: Senate Democrats Unite Behind Revised Elections Legislation
summary: New proposal, like bill passed by House, is expected to struggle to gain GOP support. WASHINGTON-A group of Senate Democrats unveiled revised elections legislation that aims to ease voters' access to the polls, a proposal that is expected to unite the party but not draw sufficient Republican support to advance.

title: Apple Dials Up a Clever Pricing Move
summary: Memory enhancements raise average price of new models while the company keeps many versions static. Apple Inc. seems to have figured out how to deliver a price increase only to customers who choose it. Many probably will.

title: 'Cheyenne & Lola' Review: Partners in Crime
summary: A far-from-fashion-conscious ex-con and a striking blonde 'spokesmodel' get caught up in a pyramid scheme-and worse-in a series on Sundance Now. Crime is usually so romanticized on screen, the demimonde so idealized, that the grimy, neo-noirish approach of "Cheyenne & Lola" feels fresh, even exhilarating. So is the way the French series snowballs through its eight episodes, accumulating subplots and momentum in a way that may make you forget how the whole avalanche of capers and outrages ever got under way.

title: Boeing CEO, Board Ask Judge to Clarify Ruling
summary: Attorneys for Boeing CEO and current and former directors asked a Delaware judge to reconsider her ruling siding with plaintiffs. Boeing Chief Executive David Calhoun and other current and former directors are asking a Delaware judge to clarify a legal opinion indicating she had found that the plane maker's board "publicly lied" about its handling of the 737 MAX.

title: Sportradar Shares Fall After Market Debut
summary: The company, which analyzes sports data and provides services to bookmakers, is part of a growing online gambling market. Sportradar Group AG , a company backed by Michael Jordan and Mark Cuban, saw its shares fall 7.2% during its first trading day, after the sports-data company raised $672 million through an initial public offering and private placements.

title: Stocks Can't Shake Off Downward Pressure
summary: S&P 500 finishes lower; index has fallen in six of the past seven trading sessions. Stocks fell on Tuesday, continuing their recent pullback even after fresh data showed that inflation climbed at a slower pace than economists expected in August.

title: Treasury Yields Fall After Consumer-Price Data
summary: Yields end the day lower after the Labor Department said the consumer-price index rose a seasonally adjusted 0.3% in August. U.S. government-bond yields fell after data showed consumer prices cooled in August, easing investors' worries about runaway inflation.

title: Revisiting Your Childhood Home Can Be Traumatic-for the Homeowners
summary: Sure, returning home may be cathartic, but it can be a bit creepy for the people who live there now. KRIS sits in her car parked on the street next to the barn, looking at the house.

title: Sha'Carri Richardson Effect: Anti-Doping Authority to Review Cannabis
summary: An advisory group will reconsider the substance's presence on the World Anti-Doping Agency's prohibited list. In the wake of American sprint champion Sha'Carri Richardson's disqualification from the Tokyo Olympics, the World Anti-Doping Agency announced Tuesday it's examining the presence of cannabis on its prohibited-substances list.

title: Toy Retailer Camp Hires Former HBO Marketing Executive
summary: Chris Spadaccini takes on role of marketing chief as Camp plans to ramp up advertising, expand across the country. New York-based toy retailer Camp NYC Inc. has hired Chris Spadaccini to be its chief marketing officer as it pursues new growth, the company said.

title: Estate Taxes Are Easy to Avoid. House Democrats Want to Change That.
summary: Some 1,900 filers paid estate tax in 2020, down from more than 50,000 two decades ago. House Democrats want more wealthy Americans to pay the estate tax.

title: Democratic Tax Plan Would Hit Million-Dollar Households Hardest, Analysis Shows
summary: Average rate for top earners would increase to 37.3% from 30.2%; low-income households would get tax cuts. WASHINGTON-Households making at least $1 million in income would face a 10.6% tax increase in 2023 under House Democrats' plan, raising their average federal tax rate to 37.3% from 30.2%, according to the nonpartisan Joint Committee on Taxation.

title: Sentinels (Wednesday Crossword, September 15)
Murder Shows Are Inspiring Vacations, From 'The Killing' to 'Shetland'
summary: Fans of grisly TV are flocking to the locations of popular detective dramas and tour companies are eager to oblige-'I've had a lot of people lie down on the crime scenes'. AFTER HE WAS laid off from a publishing job, in 2009, Lewis Swan, a passionate James Bond fan based in London, thought he could build a business around touring film locations seen in blockbuster British franchises like Bond and Harry Potter. Brit Movie Tours took off, but it wasn't long before requests took an unexpected turn for the homicidal. "There was a huge appetite for murder crime shows," Mr. Swan recalled.

title: U.S., EU Seek Global Pledge to Slash Methane Emissions by 2030
summary: Deal calls for 30% cut world-wide in human-caused emissions of the potent greenhouse gas. Officials in the U.S. and European Union are crafting a pledge to reduce global methane emissions by nearly a third by 2030, and pushing several of the world's largest economies to join them, according to people familiar with the effort.

title: The Best and Worst of Wine on TV, From 'Friday Night Lights' to 'Emily in Paris'
summary: When our wine columnist watches television, she can't help noticing what the characters are drinking-and, too often, wondering what on earth the writers were thinking. WINE IS FOR SNOBS. Wine is for drunks. And white wine is the universal drink of choice for women. This is what I learned watching a great deal of television these past several weeks in preparation for this special TV issue of Off Duty. I had hoped to see wine woven into plots in some creative ways. Spoiler alert: I did not.

title: U.S. Spies See Signs of al Qaeda's Return to Afghanistan
summary: CIA official shares findings as Antony Blinken continues Capitol Hill defense of U.S. withdrawal. WASHINGTON-U.S. intelligence agencies are seeing early signs that al Qaeda militants have begun to return to Afghanistan, a senior official said Tuesday, after they dispersed from the country in response to the U.S. counterterrorism effort there.

title: The Rising Shame of Not Knowing Someone's Name
summary: Can we have an Amnesty Day to finally ask what to call that chatty neighbor, or that parent of your kid's friend?. You meet some neighbors when your kids are small, and from that point on you bump into them often at school functions or the supermarket or soccer games where your children get obliterated by the big, scary team from upstate.

title: Chevron to Triple Low-Carbon Investment
summary: Oil giant plans to spend $10 billion through 2028 on technologies such as biofuels and hydrogen. Chevron Corp. is tripling spending in its new low-carbon unit, which Chief Executive Mike Wirth said he increasingly sees as a viable business.

title: World's Oil Supply Pressured by Hurricane Ida, Other Outages
summary: International Energy Agency cites Delta variant in trimming oil-demand forecast for third quarter. The impact of Hurricane Ida and other oil supply outages will take a sizable chunk out of global oil production this year, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday.

title: Inflation Eased in August, Though Still High
summary: Consumer-price index rose 5.3% from a year before as supplies and labor continued to drive up prices. Inflation cooled slightly in August but remained strong, as a surge in Covid-19 infections slowed economic growth and pandemic-related shortages of labor and supplies continued to drive up prices.

title: JPMorgan Chases the Online Investing Boom With Senior Hires
summary: Bank is adding two executives to reinvigorate its online investing platforms. JPMorgan Chase & Co . is hiring two executives to revamp its online investing product, which has lagged behind rival internet brokerages during a boom in individual investing.

title: U.K. Bets on Covid-19 Booster Shots to Avoid Winter Lockdowns
summary: Prime Minister Boris Johnson hopes to avoid social distancing, mask mandates and other restrictions. LONDON-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson presented a suite of measures including booster Covid-19 vaccinations for people over 50 as he aims to avoid new lockdowns this fall while keeping social-distancing restrictions to a bare minimum.

title: China Rules Against Sexual-Harassment Accuser in Closely Watched Case
summary: A court's ruling was a blow to the efforts of Chinese women's-right activists amid a fledgling #MeToo movement. BEIJING-A Beijing court ruled against the accuser in a closely-watched sexual-harassment case Tuesday, delivering a blow to Chinese civil-society activists who have fought to sustain a fledgling women's-rights movement.

title: Chauvin, Other Former Officers Plead Not Guilty to Violating Floyd's Rights
summary: Attorneys for defendants seek to separate cases, given publicity over Chauvin's conviction for second-degree murder. Derek Chauvin and three other former Minneapolis police officers pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to federal charges that they violated the civil rights of George Floyd during the arrest in May 2020 that killed him.

title: What's in the Democrats' Tax Plan? Increases in Capital Gains and Corporate Tax Rates
summary: Corporate tax rate would rise to 26.5% from 21%; capital-gains taxes would also go up. WASHINGTON-House Democrats on Monday released the full details of their plan to pay for a bevy of new social programs aimed at expanding access to paid family leave, education and healthcare, and combating climate change.

title: How Chandler Bing and Jerry Seinfeld Became 2021's Biggest Fashion Icons
summary: During their 1990s heyday, Must-See-TV characters were seen as dowdy. Today, they've become unlikely style influences for high-fashion brands and Gen Z. Why their normcore looks are resonating.. IN THE 1990s, NBC's Thursday night "Must See TV" lineup included sitcoms like "Friends," "Frasier" and "Seinfeld" that earned stratospheric ratings and Emmys galore. What they didn't receive was praise for their clothes. Few people considered the blue button-ups and flouncy khakis of Ross Geller, Dr. Frasier Crane and Jerry Seinfeld's eponymous TV alter-ego the peak of fashion. You can find articles declaring that "Seinfeld had the worst clothes" published as recently as 2017.

title: 'Failing Schools'? How About Parents?
summary: Behold the structural rot that leaves children uneducated.. Regarding William McGurn's "The Real Structural Racism" (Main Street, Sept. 7): As a high-school English teacher for the Los Angeles Unified School District, I was always amazed that with each new school year the incoming ninth-graders had a second-grade reading level. This revelation often came alongside a new and expensive mandatory reading program that would cost LAUSD millions of dollars annually. (If you have no scruples and want to make a lot of money, become a consultant for public schools.) The programs promised to boost reading levels by several grades within a year. Suffice to say, those gains never materialized. But the program would be renamed and resold every two years or so.

title: The Fed's Record of Failure With Quantitative Easing
summary: The central bank used to recognize that markets allocate credit better than government agencies.. In "Congress Needs to Rein In a Too-Powerful Federal Reserve" (op-ed, Sept. 2), Judy Shelton is correct that the Fed's bond-buying program, commonly known as quantitative easing, is distorting the allocation of credit while increasing income inequality. She might also have noted that QE broke an over 60-year policy of not interfering with the allocation of credit.

title: Is America One Family Under God?
summary: When both nationalism and the family are under attack, it doesn't help to confuse the two.. Former Sen. Joe Lieberman writes that if we realized "we are all children of the same God, all members of the same national family," then it "would be harder to treat each other as enemies" ("Jewish Tradition and National Unity," Houses of Worship, Sept. 10).

title: Medicate and Punish: For Boys, Schools Have Little to Offer
summary: The education system became less friendly and then intolerant of male characteristics and behavior.. Regarding "'I Just Feel Lost.' Young Men Abandon College" (Page One, Sept. 7): I worked in all-boys schools for 31 years, the last 21 as headmaster, and I have seen this trend evolve over time. What began as a well-intentioned and now quite successful endeavor to bring access to education and professional opportunities to a wider class of women has had unintended consequences.

title: 'Blue' Review: Opera in the Age of Black Lives Matter
summary: The story of a Black police officer's family struck by tragedy when their son is killed by a white police officer..

title: George Will Went From Flinging Newspapers to Writing Pulitzer Prize-Winning Pieces
summary: Resume Subscription. George F. Will, 80, is a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for the Washington Post and a TV commentator. He is the author of 16 books, including his latest collection of columns, "American Happiness and Discontents" (Hachette). He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Will Biden's Vaccine Mandates Hold Up?
summary: Government can compel shots, but federal or state government is the question.. President Biden's decision to compel workers at large companies to receive Covid-19 vaccines, a strategy to get as many Americans vaccinated as possible, has provoked a predictable uproar. Much of the outrage has been purely political, but opponents have raised serious questions that deserve a respectful response.

title: Towns and Cities Should Use Their Stimulus Windfalls to Cut Taxes
summary: States can't do it, but there's nothing stopping local governments from issuing refunds.. Since the passage of the American Rescue Plan Act in March, state policy makers have fiercely debated how to spend nearly $200 billion in stimulus funds. Few Americans, however, have heard plans for the $130 billion that went to cities and counties.

title: Dogecoin Copycats? Trademark Fight Erupts Over Joke Crypto Worth Billions
summary: Resume Subscription. A dogfight is breaking out over who has claim to the dogecoin name.

title: Boeing Raises Outlook on Travel Rebound
summary: Aerospace company forecasts a $9 trillion market for its products over the next decade, with the pandemic wiping out two years of growth. Boeing Co. forecast it will take another two years for the hardest-hit regional and long-haul air travel slowed by the coronavirus pandemic to return to precrisis levels.

title: What's Your Raise Really Worth? Inflation Has Something to Say About It.
summary: Resume Subscription. This should be the best of times for low-wage workers, as pandemic-induced labor shortages force employers to sharply raise pay. Yet for many, it doesn't feel that way, because those same disruptions have pushed inflation to near its highest rate in over a decade.

title: New Orleans Saints Covid-19 Cases Will Test NFL's Pandemic Strategy
summary: The cases inside the team will be the first major challenge for the NFL's second pandemic season and highlight the league's decision to test weekly, instead of daily, in 2021. Eight members of the New Orleans Saints have tested positive for Covid-19, according to two people familiar with the matter, in a developing situation that represents the first major test of the revamped protocols for the NFL's second pandemic season.

title: Goldman Sachs CFO Stephen Scherr to Retire
summary: Leveraged-finance banker Denis Coleman to succeed Scherr, who will leave at the end of the year. Goldman Sachs Group Inc . Chief Financial Officer Stephen Scherr is retiring from the Wall Street powerhouse.

title: A Quiz for TV Nerds: Where Were Your Favorite Shows Actually Filmed?
summary: These seven TV series, from 'Hacks' to 'The Crown,' created fictional worlds-but do you know where they were really shot?. ART HAS ALWAYS inspired dreams of travel, and the moving image began feeding the fantasies of restless American audiences almost from the moment of its invention. Thousands surely dreamed of heading to Egypt after viewing 1923's "The Ten Commandments," with its evocative visions of the City of the Pharaoh and haunting deserts-even though the movie was filmed primarily on the dunes of the Central California coast.

title: For the Fed, Inflation Doesn't Matter...for Now
summary: The central bank's near-term plans are unlikely to be swayed by inflation readings over the next few months. When it comes to Federal Reserve interest-rate policy, what inflation is doing now matters much less than what it will be doing next spring.

title: In Florida, Coastal Counties Fuel Population Growth-and Climate Concerns
summary: Growth along the shorelines means more people face risks from rising sea levels and severe-weather events. Roughly 16 million Floridians, or three-quarters of the state, live in coastal counties vulnerable to climate-related issues such as rising sea levels and flooding. Those 35 counties have gained nearly six million residents since 1990. Florida was the eighth fastest-growing state in the past decade and is home to eight of the 20 fastest-growing coastal counties, according to data recently released by the Census Bureau.

title: Trial Over Killing of Activist Drives Dissent Against Palestinian Leadership
summary: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas faces growing pressure after repeatedly delaying elections. RAMALLAH, West Bank-A Palestinian military court began the trial of 14 members of its security forces who are accused of beating to death a critic of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, in a case that has highlighted what activists say is the growing reach of paramilitary troops in the West Bank and a creeping culture of authoritarianism.

title: Democrats Hear Conflicting Messages From Voters on $3.5 Trillion Plan
summary: In Virginia, centrist Rep. Abigail Spanberger balances push for new spending on safety net with worries about inflation, profligacy. CULPEPER, Va.-On a telephone town hall hosted by the seniors' group AARP on Thursday night, Rep. Abigail Spanberger was peppered with questions about how to lower the cost of prescription drugs and support caregivers, two important planks of the $3.5 trillion spending package Democrats on Capitol Hill are currently crafting.

title: Iranian Guards Harassed Female U.N. Nuclear Inspectors, Diplomats Say
summary: Allegations come amid rising tensions between Tehran and the U.N. atomic energy agency. Iranian security guards have physically harassed several female United Nations atomic agency inspectors at a nuclear facility over the past few months, diplomats say, and the U.S. has demanded that Iran stop the behavior immediately.

title: Oracle, Apple, Lucid: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Oracle is slipping after an earnings report; Apple is edging up ahead of its iPhone reveal event. U.S. stock futures edged higher ahead of fresh data that is likely to show that inflation remained elevated in August. Futures tied to the S&P 500 and the Dow ticked up almost 0.2%, indicating that both indexes will post tepid gains after the opening bell.

title: Covid-19 Likely to Overshadow Afghanistan, Abortion Rights and Spending Plans in Midterm Elections
summary: Pandemic's trajectory and impact remain the top concerns for both Democratic and Republican voters. WASHINGTON-When Republican strategist Christopher Nicholas polls voters in Pennsylvania, Covid-19 is such a dominating concern that he asks: Aside from the pandemic, what other issue is important to you? When Democratic Rep. Vicente Gonzalez considers what's top of mind in his Texas district, Covid-19 is the clear answer.

title: Steven Cohen to Invest in New Crypto Quant Trading Firm
summary: New firm, called Radkl, to be led by partners of high-speed trading firm GTS. Billionaire Steven A. Cohen is set to invest in a new cryptocurrency trading firm, the latest bet on the digital-asset markets by a prominent Wall Street investor.

title: Lisa Rinna Does Not Believe in Rules, Beauty or Otherwise
summary: "I do whatever I want whenever I want." The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills fan favorite, social media sensation and beauty impresario on elaborate product rituals, good genes and weaning her husband off baby oil.. Lisa Rinna's mouth-or, more specifically, what comes out of it-has been known to get her into plenty of hot water on The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills, so it's fitting that her 10-month-old brand Rinna Beauty launched with a set of lip products. The actress, 58, who has been gracing the small screen since the 1990s on shows like Days of Our Lives and Melrose Place, has in recent years found a new audience on the Real Housewives reality franchise. And on Instagram, her dance numbers and savage comments-she left a smiley face emoji on a post about her daughter Amelia's breakup with Scott Disick-have made her a viral hit. (Her follower count stands at 2.9 million.) The celebrity beauty field is more crowded than ever, with recent news of lines from Ariana Grande, Scarlett Johansson, Jennifer Aniston and Harry Styles. As of now, Rinna Beauty is focused exclusively on lips, an intentional move since it's the feature Rinna herself is perhaps best known for. "My lips have had their own career," she says of her iconic pout.

title: Just Won a Crazy Game, Baby! Raider Fans Debut in Vegas
summary: An itinerant franchise opens a new stadium to a regular-season crowd-and rewards them with a stunning overtime victory. Las Vegas

title: How 'Go Your Own Way' Helped Lindsey Buckingham Get Over Stevie Nicks
summary: The 1976 breakup song was a way forward for Fleetwood Mac. Following his romantic breakup with bandmate Stevie Nicks in 1975, Fleetwood Mac guitarist Lindsey Buckingham was desolate. In an attempt to move beyond the rejection that left bitter feelings, he wrote "Go Your Own Way."

title: Soaring Rents Make It a Very Good Time to Own an Apartment Building
summary: The 10% rise in national asking rents in August is highest on record, helped by more young workers returning to cities. Despite a yearlong national eviction ban and continuing pandemic, it has rarely been a better time to be a big apartment-building landlord.

title: Malls Bounce Back but Brace for Tough Fall Season
summary: Nicer weather got people out of the house, while newly vaccinated Americans felt better being around strangers in enclosed spaces, analysts say. U.S. shopping malls have enjoyed a busy summer despite the spread of the Covid-19 Delta variant, providing a much-needed boost to retailers and property owners.

title: Pimco Sets Its Sights on Commercial Real Estate
summary: As the Covid-19 pandemic reduces property values, the bond investor pursues higher yields by acquiring hotels and office buildings. Pimco, one of the world's largest fixed-income investors, has been ramping up its commercial real-estate holdings at the same time that historically low interest rates have undercut bond returns.

title: Facebook Knows Instagram Is Toxic for Teen Girls, Company Documents Show
summary: Resume Subscription. About a year ago, teenager Anastasia Vlasova started seeing a therapist. She had developed an eating disorder, and had a clear idea of what led to it: her time on Instagram.

title: South Korea Fines Google for Thwarting Potential Android Rivals
summary: South Korean regulator also investigating fair trade issues with Google's app store practices, in-app purchases and advertising. SEOUL-South Korea fined Alphabet Inc.'s Google around $177 million for obstructing other companies from developing rival versions of the Android operating system, the latest challenge to the U.S. technology giant's dominance in mobile software.

title: The SPAC Bubble Is Burst. It May Be Time to Invest.
summary: While the SPAC boom has fizzled, blank-check vehicles are now trading at deep enough discounts for even skeptical investors to consider arbitrage trades. Interest in special-purpose acquisition companies has faded fast. As old investors mourn their losses, though, it may be time for new ones to raid the spoils.

title: Evergrande's Cash Problem is Now Beijing's Political Problem
summary: Protesters crowded the headquarters of China's most indebted property developer after some wealth-management products it backed failed to pay out on time. Indebted property developer China Evergrande is struggling with the protests of disgruntled investors. Cries from buyers of its apartments could grow even louder.

title: Apple, Google Could Win From App Store Loss
summary: User friction, developer marketing needs could offset loss of payment exclusivity. Apple Inc. and Google have ways to mitigate last week's damaging legal ruling regarding their app store businesses. Ironically, their ability to do so could also prove their critics' point.

title: What to Know About Flu Vaccine as Covid-19 Pandemic Continues
summary: Some health experts warn of a possible 'twindemic' of flu and coronavirus infections. Here is how to protect yourself.. Doctors expect more flu cases this season, after the virus barely registered last cycle when coronavirus precautions such as mask wearing and social distancing also reduced the spread of other viruses.

title: BP Taps Renewable Power Specialist in Green Energy Push
summary: Oil major hires former RWE Renewables CEO Anja-Isabel Dotzenrath to head its low-carbon operations. LONDON- BP PLC has hired the former chief executive of one of the world's largest wind power developers to run its gas and low-carbon operations, as the oil giant looks to support its push into renewable energy.

title: Chinese Audio Platform to List in Hong Kong After Scrapping U.S. IPO Plans
summary: Ximalaya in April filed a draft prospectus for an IPO in the U.S.. The owner of a popular podcast and audio platform in China filed for an initial public offering in Hong Kong shortly after scrapping plans to list in New York, showing how a Chinese regulatory crackdown on U.S. listings is forcing homegrown tech companies to change course.

title: China Evergrande Hires Financial Advisers as Protests Erupt at Its Offices
summary: Developer warns of slower sales and possibility of cross default on its debts. China Evergrande Group moved closer to a potential restructuring of its $89 billion debt burden by hiring outside advisers, while the property developer's financial problems spilled over into angry protests at several of its offices.

title: U.S., Europe Seek to End Export Financing for Coal
summary: Wealthy nations move to end support for a fuel that is one of the world's biggest sources of greenhouse gases. PARIS-The U.S., the European Union, South Korea and other wealthy nations are moving to forbid their export-financing agencies from supporting coal-fired power projects overseas, in an effort to end government support for a fuel that is one of the world's biggest sources of greenhouse gases.

title: Tropical Storm Nicholas Brings Heavy Rain to Texas
summary: National Hurricane Center warns of flash flooding; Louisiana governor says storm could disrupt some Ida-related power restoration. Hurricane Nicholas made landfall on the Texas coast early Tuesday, bringing heavy rains, strong winds and storm surges to parts of the central and upper coasts of the state, before being downgraded to a tropical storm.

title: DeFi Is Crypto's Wall Street, Without a Safety Net
summary: Decentralized finance allows crypto enthusiasts a do-it-yourself version of investment banking, bringing high rewards and huge risks. "Trade. Earn. Win." The happy bunny flipping a pancake and the double- or triple-digit interest rates on offer are closer to the marketing style of Las Vegas than Wall Street. Don't be fooled: PancakeSwap and its competitors in what's now known as DeFi, or decentralized finance, are bringing casino capitalism to the crypto masses.

title: Offices Reopen With Safety Plans, but Commutes Spook Workers
summary: Some employees push back against returning to the workplace, saying they are reluctant to use trains and buses during the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies are trying to arrange the safe return of workers to big-city offices, but one factor remains beyond their control: the mass-transit commute.

title: Asia's Covid-19 Success Stories Warily Ponder Post-Vaccination Moves
summary: As vaccination rates climb, countries such as Singapore and South Korea consider how fast to ease strategies that have minimized infections and deaths. Earlier this month, Singapore reached a Covid-19 milestone: The fully vaccinated portion of the population crossed 80%. But instead of moving ahead with a planned reopening pegged to the achievement, the government put on the brakes.

title: Stock Buybacks Beat Capital Spending for Many Big Companies
summary: Finance chiefs at S&P 500 companies spent more on buybacks than on plowing back into their businesses in the first half of the year. Some finance chiefs say they have plenty of money to invest in their businesses, but shortages in the equipment and people needed for new projects are limiting how much they can take on, leaving a lot of excess cash for buying back stock.

title: The Zero-Trust Approach to Managing Cyber Risk Explained
summary: Biden administration's cybersecurity mandate pushes federal agencies to trust no one in their computer networks. The Biden administration is pushing federal agencies to adopt a cybersecurity philosophy that has become increasingly popular in the private sector amid a growing shift toward cloud computing and a surge in cyberattacks: trust nothing.

title: Pay for Company Directors Stalled Last Year
summary: Median pay for board members held steady at $310,000 at the biggest 100 companies. Pay for directors at the biggest U.S. companies held steady last year, a first in more than a decade.

title: Taliban's Pledge of Amnesty for Security Officials Meets Widespread Distrust
summary: War's bloody legacy means some fighters exact revenge killings despite leaders' official prohibition. GHAZNI, Afghanistan-As Taliban fighters cradling trophy assault rifles crowded a police headquarters base here, the new boss explained the new rules.

title: Kroger, Instacart Aim for 30-Minute Grocery Delivery
summary: Partnership draws supermarket giant further into a crowded market. Kroger Co. said it is partnering with Instacart Inc. to deliver food and household staples in as little as 30 minutes, bringing the supermarket giant further into a crowded grocery-delivery business.

title: Biden Campaigns for Newsom, Views Wildfire Damage in Western Swing
summary: President meets with fire-agency officials, promotes infrastructure and climate-related legislative proposals. LONG BEACH, Calif.-President Biden held a rally for Gov. Gavin Newsom ahead of Tuesday's recall election, the last in a string of high-profile Democrats to visit the state in an attempt to drive Democratic voter turnout and defeat the effort.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Apple Cyber Flaw Allows Silent iPhone Hack Through iMessage
summary: Security researchers say Israel's NSO Group has been exploiting the vulnerability since February. An Israeli cybersecurity firm has been exploiting a significant Apple Inc. software vulnerability since February to silently infect iPhones using iMessage, the company's messaging software, according to the research group that discovered the issue.

title: Bill Gates Says We Aren't Ready for the Next Pandemic
summary: Tens of millions have fallen into extreme poverty during the Covid-19 pandemic, Gates Foundation says. Bill Gateswarned six years ago that the biggest potential killer the world faced was a pandemic.

title: Senate Republicans Vow to Block Treasury Nominations Until Nord Stream II Firm Is Sanctioned
summary: Top Treasury nominations include sanctions, counterterror finance chiefs. WASHINGTON-Senior Senate Republicans on Monday threatened to indefinitely hold up the nominations of five top Treasury Department officials if the Biden administration doesn't blacklist the firm managing Russia's Nord Stream 2 pipeline project.
